title: Monday, 1st August, 2016

A quick explanation from Adam Lerrick

PM

Who's a bank bailout trouble shooter from the US

PM

We almost made it.

However, in the end, the ECB and the European Commission accepted two
questionable conditions in the Monte dei Paschi restructuring. This ensured
that there is no bail-in before the October 2016 Italian referendum that could
jeopardize Renzi's government.

11:05 am
PM

1. Securitization of Bad Loans at Above Market Price

Monte dei Paschi will securitize bad loans with a book value of EUR 27.7 billion
based upon a transfer price of 33% compared to a market price of 20-25%.

The securitization at the above-market purchase price of the loans is possible
because the captive Atlas fund (owned by Italian official institutions, banks and
pension funds) will accept a 5-6% return on the junior debt tranche instead of
the market 10-15% rate.

PM

2. An Underwriting Commitment with No Commitment

The pre-underwriting agreement of the bank consortium for the EUR 5 billion
share sale is conditional upon positive feedback from investors.

In my youth, this was called "best efforts".

The share sale is scheduled to be completed in December 2016 or the first quarter
of 2017.

Adam

PM

MPS currently up 4.6 per cent in Milan

11:07 am

BE

All of which are equally buggered. Is that a fair summary?

11:09 am
PM

PM

Over in Ireland they're claiming the stress test was unfair

PM

Too stressful

11:09 am
PM

Here's Goodbody

PM

The EBA has published its stress test results on 51 banks. On transitional capital (EBA’s
primary measure), the adverse scenario impact was –380bps to 9.4%. AIB’s adverse
scenario capital ratio is -850bps to 7.4%, with BOI -560bps at 7.7%. The Irish banks are in
the bottom 8 of the test. On fully loaded capital (effective 2018), upon which markets will
likely assign most weight, BOI’s adverse scenario capital is 6.15% (-513bps) and AIB at
4.31% (-880bps), 2 of the 4 lowest ranked banks. Whilst not published, PTSB was part of
the private ECB tests, so also likely fared poorly.

PM

In our view, the stress test methodology has been harsh on Ireland. We estimate the
adverse scenario loan default rate is on a par, or actually exceeds, the peak NPL level
recorded in Ireland in 2013 after the economic meltdown which required a Troika-led bailout
in 2010-13. That strikes us as particularly harsh! Elsewhere, retention of the expensive 10%
cocos, repaid this weekend, were also a factor, costing AIB c.1.0% point of capital in the test
period and 0.5% at BOI.

11:10 am
PM

The test outcome may pressure Irish bank equity & credit prices in the short term.
However, the tests do not drive additional capital requirements, but are an input to
the year-end SREP assessment, posing a risk that SREP requirements in Q416 drift
up. However, it’s against a backdrop of significant buffers against existing targets.
BOI’s SREP is 10.25% (transitional) vs its H116 transitional CET1 ratio of 12.8%
and 10.7% fully loaded, both estimated to rise 75bps in H216. AIB hasn’t divulged
its SREP, but its H116 transitional CET1 ratio was 16.5% and 13.3% fully loaded,
both forecast to rise 90bps in H2. We are buyers on any post stress test weakness.

PM

As for the Brits...

PM

Not many surprises there

11:10 am
Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 187.92, down 4.48 (-2.33%), High: 193.00, Low: 187.30, Volume: 6.96m
Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 150.90, down 3.65 (-2.36%), High: 157.25, Low: 149.85, Volume: 19.84m
BE

Yep ... quick chart from Morgan Stanley ...........

11:11 am
BE

BE

And on the UK'ers .....

BE

While it's interesting to see how the UK banks fared in the EBA stress tests we see limited direct implications for capital build and potential distribution. This is because the Bank of England is in the process of running its own stress tests (results due in Q4 2016) with these tests being the key driver of capital requirements for the UK banks (vs. the Eurozone banks, which are subject to SSM SREP). The UK banks saw drawdowns averaging 398bps in this year's EBA test, ahead of the European average of 335bps as well as vs. the 2014 drawdowns. Lloyds and HSBC fared best with c.300bps of drawdown while Barclays saw 400bps and RBS a very substantial 750bps. However, given the lower starting point Barclays fared the worst in terms of 2018 adverse CET1 with a stressed ratio of 7.3% followed by RBS with 8.1%, HSBC 8.8% and Lloyds at 10.1%.
The EBA stress tests have historically not proved a good lead indicator of results in the BoE stress tests with, Lloyds, HSBC and RBS all seeing higher stresses in the 2014 BoE stress tests vs. the EBA test (and Barclays seeing lower stress). While the BoE stress test scenarios do look tougher than the EBA's test this doesn't necessarily have to imply the UK banks will fare worse given the methodologies differ substantially – for example the EBA assumes static balance sheet and floors costs at the 2015 level. However, we do know the BOE's test will be run at a much higher threshold than in the past, set at the sum of Pillar 1 + Pillar 2a + G-SIFI requirements. We estimate this means the UK banks will need to have a stressed CET1 ratio above a 1 Jan 2019 'systemic reference point' (SRP) of 6.5-9.3% (pre-RWA inflation).
Both Barclays and RBS's EBA test results screen as below their respective SRP's. Barclays' 2019 end state SRP is 8.7% (although we note that the company indicated an SRP of 7.6% in its press release post the EBA test, likely lower vs. our end state due to phase-in assumptions) and for RBS we estimate 9.3%. For RBS the quantum of drawdown in the EBA test was very substantial even compared with the BOE's own tests (750bps vs. BOE 500bps last year). It looks like this was due to a combination of very weak PPOP (including stressed conduct costs), a severe asset quality outcome and substantial RWA inflation. As such, the inclusion of some benefit for cost savings and/or business disposals should result in a less severe outcome in the BOE test. We continue to expect the BOE tests could prove challenging this year. However, if they do reveal a shortfall we would expect
the BOE to give credit for the already announced plans (and initial progress towards) the selldown of Africa and run off of non-core, which we estimate will add over 200bps to the CET1 ratio by end 2018, lifting the CET1 ratio above potential requirements.

11:21 am
BE

Our view: With the balance sheet striding towards rehabilitation and
volume improvements in H2, Anglo's rating likely to improve. Further,
divestments provide catalysts for the shares. We upgrade to Outperform,
with a £10/sh Price Target.

BE

Key points:
Upgrading on positive pointers from H1: We have adjusted our forecasts
post the H1 figures; this and good progress on debt, costs, capex and
productivity, has led us to increase our Price Target to £10/sh. Our
recommendation is upgraded to Outperform. Risks remain commodity
prices, South Africa and the impact of any GBP strength on the share price.
Good H1 results: H1 results came in above consensus and our forecasts
despite disappointing production from Copper (Los Bronces). Across the
group there was a strong effort to control or reduce costs (helped by
currencies) and capex was controlled. In H2 there should be a greater
benefit on costs from volumes, productivity and cost cutting (including
headcount). While there will be lower activity in diamonds for seasonality
reasons, volumes in Copper, Coal and Iron Ore should improve and Anglo
expects to achieve its $1.6bn annual cost reduction; it could even do
better.
Balance sheet starts to look respectable: The higher level of net debt is
being reeled in with $1.1bn of free cash flow in H1 contributing to the
reduction from $12.9bn at end-December 2015 to $11.7m at end-June.
The target remains below $10bn for the year (we calculate $9.5bn), which
seems certain given after-tax proceeds of ~$1.4bn from the May sale of
Phosphates & Niobium and additional internal cash generation despite the
likely non-recurence of the $500m working inflow in H1 as De Beers and
Kumba have no surplus inventory now. As important as the net debt target
is that Anglo moved below the 2.5x goal in terms of net debt:EBITDA after
adjusting for the sale of Phosphates & Niobium.

BE

Assets sales continue: Anglo faced many questions from analysts on
whether it still needed to dispose of assets given an improving balance
sheet. The company reiterated its target of being only invested in Copper,
Diamonds and PGMs, but did acknowledge that achieving value for assets
could influence the disposal timeline. We believe the next assets likely to
be sold will be the Australian metcoal mines for a price of up to $1.5bn.
Dividend returns by end-FY17: At the end of next year Anglo targets
resuming dividend payments, based on a payout ratio rather than the
previous "progressive" policy. We conservatively assume a payout of
$0.25/sh for FY18 though success on asset sales could make our timing
conservative. The message is that Anglo is confident the balance sheet
and debt rating will justify resuming dividends. This is a positive message
which should help mitigate Anglo's elevated exposure to South Africa.

11:23 am
PM

Cautious on price outlook, stronger Rand, and SA risks (inflation, regulation)
We downgraded Anglo to Sell in Mar-16 as in our opinion the risk/ reward was not
compelling after the strong share price recovery. We were concerned about 1) the
near-term price outlook; 2) execution risk with the "radical restructuring"; 3) the
balance sheet risk in a lower for longer price environment. Commodity prices (esp iron
ore & coal) and diamond volumes have been stronger than expected in H1; this has
reduced the restructuring & balance sheet risks, and driven a material recovery in cash
flow/ EPS and re-rating of the share (which is up 250% since Jan). We remain cautious
on the share as we expect iron ore & thermal coal prices to fall greater than 15% in H2, with
copper, diamond and platinum prices to remain depressed (see Miners' Price Review of
7-Jul); we also see potential for EPS to disappoint in H2/2017 due to the stronger Rand

PM

They have one of these Q&A things you like and which i don't

PM

ut here it is

11:23 am
PM

Q: Can Anglo raise US$7bn from disposals?
Yes. We estimate the market value of all Anglo's non-core assets at US$9.5bn, but in our opinion it
will take Anglo over 3 years to exit all the assets. As a result, we still believe Anglo's medium-term net
debt target of ~US$6bn is challenging, assuming commodity prices remain depressed.
"Anglo American: Revisiting the sum of parts valuation" 07/06/2016
Q: Is the recent uptick in platinum and diamond prices sustainable?
No. The "New Anglo American" will generate ~70% of EBITDA from diamonds and platinum, and so
the outlook for these comodities is key to the investment case. We believe the fundamentals for
platinum and diamonds remain challenging and a material recovery in prices is unlikely.
"Anglo American: Risk/ reward not attractive; downgrade to Sell" 07/03/2016
Q: Does Anglo need additional capital over the next 2 years if prices return to lows?
In our opinion, no. We believe Anglo has a well-structured balance sheet with good liquidity, no
covenants at the group level, and limited refinancing in FY16/17. Our main concern is the absolute
level of debt relative to the cash flow generation of the business. We see the balance sheet risk
increasing beyond FY18 if commodity prices weaken and if Anglo is not able to sell assets...

11:26 am
PM

Even economists like to have a little summer fun, at least every four years.

PM

GS: The Olympics and Economics 2016: Modelling Medal Success in Rio

PM

Francesco Garzarelli and team

11:27 am
PM

Even economists like to have a little summer fun, at least every four years. In the
quadrennial Olympics and Economics report that follows, we explore the link
between a country’s economic, political and institutional traits and its medal
success, and we update our ever-popular medal predictions model to forecast
country medal counts at the Rio Games. We also explore the economic benefits (if
any) of hosting the Olympics—a question that’s top of mind with the prolonged
contraction in Brazil.
Before we (and the Games) begin, a few fun findings from our analysis:

PM

n Hosting is gold. Our model predicts a 30% boost to Brazil’s overall medal tally
relative to 2012 and a greater than 50% boost to gold alone—bringing their total
to a record 22.
n Just not for the economy. The ~US$10bn spent on infrastructure and logistics is
too small to stimulate Brazil’s US$1.8 trillion economy.
n Or the guy who hosted last time. Expect the UK to lose 10% of its 2012 medal
tally at the Rio Games, but still end third in the overall medals table.
n The key to standing on the podium is sitting down. If you’re the UK, that is.
Jokes aside, statistics show the country dominates in rowing, cycling and other
seated sports.
n There’s an indoor/outdoor factor. The UK and Brazil are among the best
outdoor sportsmen, while many Asian countries fare better inside.
n Starting something doesn’t mean you’ll finish well. Greece, the birthplace of
the Olympics, has poor sporting performance relative to what its economic
indicators suggest it could achieve.
n It’s not a two-man race. The US and China dominate in total medals, but not in
every sport. Whom to watch: Italian fencers, Korean archers and Brazilian
volleyballers.

PM

Here's what Citi makes of it all.

BE

(I haven't had feltcollaredsource s complain at me for a week and a half. I'm basically just inviting it today.)

11:33 am
BE

Two steps closer to completion

1) ABI received regulatory clearance from China’s MOFCOM, meeting the final ‘pre-condition’; 2) SAB Board recommended ABI’s improved offer, proposing, however, that Altria and BevCo are treated as a separate class of shareholders for voting purposes in the Scheme. This effectively means that a 75% majority of the free-float will be required to approve the Scheme of Arrangement. While this is a high hurdle to clear, we continue to believe the deal is very likely to go through, with index tracking funds (~11% of free float), risk/arbs (~1/3 of free float, we believe), most shareholders with cross-holdings in ABI or MolsonCoors, and other shareholders too, likely to vote in favour in our opinion. The board’s positive recommendation should sway investors too.

BE

Oh, and the excellent Pablo Zuanic at SIG downgrades BUD this morning.

BE

(SIG as in Susquehanna.) Zuanic's called this right throughout, pretty much. He says it's done, dusted, nothing left to play for.

11:35 am
BE

With the SAB deal almost completed (after Friday’s Board recommendation following China regulatory approval, only the shareholder vote is pending…), we introduce our pro forma estimates (factoring all divestitures). But we are downgrading to Neutral on valuation (price target $147) and lack of further catalysts.

BE

Summary: After taking a detailed look at BUD on a pro forma basis (factoring in the $2.45Bn synergies over three years as opposed to guidance for four years; factoring in announced divestitures, and taking the latest bid structure) and valuing BUD by taking a 10% peer premium on our F&B universe, we arrive at a share price of $147 by December ’16. Given this is below the SIG threshold for a Positive rating (of 15% upside), we switch to a Neutral stance. We think downside is minimal ($110 taking 20x on 2018 EPS). Potential sources of upside would include: a) higher synergies (but SAB’s consolidated margins are not far below BUD’s, and we note $2.4Bn of targeted cost savings and synergies are close to 20 points of the $12Bn new sales after all divestitures including the ones in Europe); b) further accretive M&A deals, but these may still be three years out (starting at 4.1x, the new BUD will still be at a lofty 2.6x by 2020; by then every point of EBITDA could help raise another $27Bn); c) emerging markets acceleration and currency appreciation (tough to factor in the current environment); and d) we do not think a potential (forced) sale of the 57% stake in CCBA (Coke bottler) would move our BUD valuation much (if KO takes away the distribution rights, BUD would be compensated); also, even if the C&E Europe SAB units are sold above our 13x EBITDA assumption, that would not move the total BUD valuation math much.

BE

Deal economics, as announced on 11/11/15, have changed somewhat.

The base for the deal was the SAB consolidated EBITDA for FY15 (March ’15), but EBITDA fell 10% in FY16.

Since November, two-thirds of the SAB currencies have depreciated against the US$, with only the Colombia peso and Australian dollar appreciating.

BUD locked the cash portion of the deal based on hedges taken at 1.5276 (actually, above the FX rate of November). As we show here, factoring the hedge, and the latest value of the stock component, the final price comes out to $114Bn.

11:36 am
BE

Can cost-savings targets really push SAB margins 20 points? EPS accretion works out to “only” 13% but that is fully factoring what, in hindsight, are aggressive cost savings and synergy targets (given where SAB margins are and commitments made in South Africa).

SAB consolidated EBITDA margin for FY16 was 34.3%, but once we factor the sale of the European business (C&E Europe is on the block, and key brands like Peroni and Grolsch were sold), the remainder of SAB has EBITDA margins of 36.2%, not far below the BUD EBITDA margins of 38.3%.

The combined target savings/synergies of $2.45Bn are equivalent to another 20 points of consolidated SAB sales ($12.1Bn ex Europe). That means SAB margins would be 56%, a tall order.

The jewel in the crown was sold, regrettably. Last, but not least, one of the reasons we were supporters of the deal as announced in November was our belief that BUD would try its best to hold on to the stake in CR Snow (to us, the jewel in the SAB crown; undoubtedly the most strategic asset in the SAB global portfolio). But as we have known now for some time, BUD decided it was necessary to sell that unit to gain regulatory approval in China. That cooled our views on the strategic value of the SAB deal.

11:39 am
BE

Whichever way, GKP "will not engage in any additional process that causes the Company to be distracted from the objective to close the ongoing restructuring transaction"

BE

So if Exxon comes knocking again with a £7 a share offer, they can just go away. There's a debt-for-equity swap and GKP's going to press the button on it no matter what.

BE

Anyway .... Canaccord upgraded -- yes, really! -- at the end of last week.

11:42 am
BE

Gulf Keystone has proposed a balance sheet restructuring, which would see the equitisation of $500m outstanding debt and coupons for 95% of the equity, leaving current shareholders with 5%. In addition, the company proposes an open offer of 20 new shares for each 9 held, at 1.09 dollar cents to raise $25m. The new equity would then own pro-forma 10% of the company, existing shares 4.5%, convertible bondholders 20%, and guaranteed noteholders 65.5% and the market value of the equity would be $250m. In addition, guaranteed noteholders would own $100m 'reinstated notes' with maturity October '21 (currently $575m maturity April and October '17) at 10% coupon (or at GKP's option 13% PIK to October '18). GKP would also have the right to raise a further $25m debt. In addition the debt service reserve account, DSRA, which required a minimum $32.5m cash to be maintained, would be removed. Assuming full subscription of the open offer the company would then have cash of c.$85m and net debt of $15m. An SGM to approve the plan is scheduled for 5th August.

Canaccord Genuity view

We think this restructuring is a lifeline for the company and current shareholders. Considering the balance sheet stress - coupon payments of $26m due in April had not been paid, $575m debt maturities looming in '17, and likely diminishing production due to limited investment capacity - shareholder dilution seemed inevitable and current equity could have suffered more than the plan elicits. Assuming approval and a fully subscribed open offer, the company's cash resources should allow it to invest in the Shaikan field (WI 58%), initially to maintain gross production around 40 kbopd, and then in the longer term to increase towards full recovery of the field's reserves (2P gross 639 mmbbls at September '15). If the restructuring is not approved, then current equity holders can expect to receive little or no value for their shares.

BE

Valuation and rating

We have assumed that the restructuring is approved and that the open offer is fully subscribed. On that basis, with a much more sustainable foundation, we think it is appropriate to base our TP on NPV15 (from NPV20) central valuation, in line with our treatment for Gulf Keystone's peers in KRI under our coverage (Genel,LSE | BUY, 91p : TP 195p; DNO, OSLO | HOLD, NOK8.35 : TP NOK10).

It is important to bear in mind that holding or buying the stock today provides the right to the open offer. So, for example, a pre-restructuring SP of 7.5p/sh would correspond to a post-restructuring average price of 2.9p/sh assuming full take up of the open offer, close to our NPV15 central valuation of 2.8p/sh.

We expect that the restructuring will be approved but beyond that there are still risks concerned with the asset and Gulf Keystone's ability to maintain and then grow production, as well as more general operational and political uncertainties in the region. Neverthless, assuming approval, we raise our rating to Speculative BUY (from Sell) with a revised TP of 7.5p/sh pre-restructuring (equivalent to 3p/sh post restructuring). Failure to pass the plan at the SGM would result in a significant downgrade for equity valuation and the future of the company.

BE

So, that's that. Good luck to all holders.

BE

NO INTENTION TO MAKE AN OFFER FOR AVANTI

Inmarsat (LSE: ISAT.L) notes the recent press speculation regarding Avanti
Communications Group plc ("Avanti"). Inmarsat confirms that it was contacted
by Avanti's advisers following the announcement by that company of a strategic
review and formal sale process on 11 July 2016, and responded to that contact.
Inmarsat confirms it has withdrawn from Avanti's announced process and it is
not considering an offer for the shares of Avanti.

This announcement is made in accordance with Rule 2.8 of the Code. As a
result, Inmarsat and any person acting in concert with it will, except with
the consent of the Takeover Panel, be bound by the restrictions contained in
Rule 2.8 of the Code.

BE

Forecast changes: reflecting the challenging underlying market conditions in
the Group's Retail (37% of Group EBITDA) and London (24% of Group
EBITDA) divisions we reduce our FY16-18 adj. EBITDA forecasts for the
divisions by an average 13% and 35% respectively. The downgrade to
numbers are driven by lower assumptions on housing transactions, where we
now expect total FY16e housing transactions to be down -10% and -15% in
the Retail and London divisions respectively. We also revise down our FY16-
18e EBITDA margin forecasts in the Retail division by an average of 170bps
and by 500bps in the London division. We make no changes to our other
divisional forecasts.

BE

1H16 Results: 1H16 EBITDA came in at £37.9m, down 8% YoY and 5%
below CS forecasts of £40.0m. Group sales increase 9% YoY to £370m, but
profitability was impacted by a 189bp decline in group EBITDA margin. The
retrenchment in margin was driven by the significantly weaker performances
in the Retail and London divisions where EBITDA margins in both divisions
contracted by 378bps YoY. This was partially offset by stronger
performances in Financial Services and B2B divisions.

11:52 am
BE

Bearish outlook and guidance: On the outlook management state that “this
period of uncertainty will inevitably impact the level of transactional activity in
the second half of the year". Consequently, management state that they now
expect FY16 EBITDA to come in below last year's EBITDA level of £113m.
Pre-results, consensus expectations were for an FY16 EBITDA of £121m.

BE

Valuation: Whilst we remain concerned over the outlook for UK housing
transactions, with the group trading on 8.4x FY17e EPS and 7.2x
EV/EBITDA, we feel this is priced in. Maintain a Neutral rating.

BE

Keller delivered significant profit growth in North America and EMEA, which
was unfortunately more than outweighed by challenging market conditions
and project delays in APAC. Our estimates are unchanged at the PBT level in
2016 (as we expect growth in North America and EMEA to outweigh losses
in APAC), we reduce our APAC profit estimates for FY17 which leads to a 4%
downgrade.

BE

H1 Highlights. Record revenue of £850m, up 12%. Operating profit £35.6m down 6% due
to APAC. EPS adj 27.4p down 12%. Dividend 9.25p up 5%. Net debt £339.7m (H1 £171.5m) moving parts acquisition of warehouse £62m and currency translation.

Estimate changes. No changes to profit estimates for FY2016E, we continue to expect PBT
of £102.3m. Turning to FY2017 we scale back our profit estimates for APAC which moves
our FY2017E PBT est. down c.4% to £106m.

Brexit Impacts. Only c.4% of group revenues are derived from the UK, virtually all
earnings and most of its debt are in foreign currencies, primarily US dollar, which is currently beneficial for the P&L and to the detriment debt.

Outlook. for 2016 as a whole the Board expects North America and EMEA to outperform
its original expectations, although this outperformance is expected to be countered by
weakness in APAC. Overall the Board expects the full-year results to be at the lower end of
their expectations, in line with our estimates.

Investment Thesis. Keller is the world's largest independent ground engineering
specialist, with permanent operations in more than 40 countries across Europe, North
America, Australia, Asia, Latin America and the Middle East. In our view, Keller is an early
cycle play within the construction sector (essentially ground engineering is the first physical
works of any construction project) and Keller has a strong record of transferring skills and
technologies across its operations and of enhancing its skill sets via acquisitions. We believe
that many of the globe's major construction markets are poised for growth and as such Keller should be of interest to investors looking for exposure to the global construction markets.
